content.description:
After doing TWBtM and Pigpen, I was allured by the line that takes you to the top of the face. I scoped what I thought were features from the ground and then set up a rope over the line. During the cleaning process, I was surprised to find that those features were little more than ripples in the rock. Fortunately, I discovered a new line of holds that offered a fantastic line to the ledge. Suprisingly, almost no loose rock was encountered during cleaning and after scrubbing off the lichen, a series of unique and solid holds revealed themselves.

 The climb starts the same as TWBtM, then midway busts out right with a lunge to a tasty dorito sidepull. From here, make some committing moves and navigate through a sloper jug, two jutting crystal holds, a grainy flat edge, and a feldspar knob to find yourself on the ledge. The true summit lies another 10-12 feet up a vertical face (uncleaned), but this seemed like a logical finish since the remaining climbing would be X-rated.

 Setting up a rope on this climb is STRONGLY recommened. A couple years back, the massive pine that shaded Indian Summer was struck by lightning and exploded. A large portion of the trunk now rests in the landing. A fall from up high on this boulder would be awkward and unpredictable at best, even with ample padding. Furthermore, there is no easy way off the ledge. Presumably, you could shuffle to the left side of the ledge and downclimb ~6 feet to the sloping top out of Indian Summer, but this scramble looked scary and insecure. While rapping is not my preferred method of descent from a boulder, it seems like a necessity here.

 If you're a highball enthusiast like me who is willing to put in a little effort to climb this thing, you will be rewarded with engaging movement and unique holds. 8b is the gift that keeps on giving.
content.protection: As many pads as possible and a spotter to keep you from tumbling off the backside of the large log in the landing. A top rope is recommended for inspection and necessary for safe descent.
content.location: Start the same as TWBtM and trend right. See attached topo photo.

content.description:
Start sitting in the middle of the face. Climb high on incut rails and edges to top out left.   

  Number 15 

  Project: Avoid the left exit and continue straight up the tall face. A top-rope inspection & cleaning is imperative before attempting.  

  Number 16

From a high triangular flake just right of the arete, make a big reach up left and top out on Those Who Bear the Mark.  

  Number 13 

*SDS (V5) = Number 14

Start as per Indian Summer (either standing or SDS), and climb into Pigpens Arête from the crimps halfway up the face. 

  Number 12

Starts matched on the two obvious crimps high on the wall and climbs the final crux of the lower start. 

  Number 9

Begin standing on good feet with your right hand on the lower of two flat underclings and a left hand sidepull. Bump right into the higher undercling and continue long moves on incuts and edges up a striking face. Beginning from a SDS alleviates some difficulty, but is permissible. 

  Recommended.

Climb the face just right of the arete to a dynamic finish. 

  Number 2

Start standing on an obvious chickenhead in the middle of the face, and find a way to make it happen. Tops out directly up the face. 

  Number 7 

  SDS: Project. SDS in the center of the wall between Indian Summer and Bear Down on small incuts, and brutalize to the chickenhead of the stand. Very thin. 

  Number 8

The low start to Bear Down. Begins low on an obvious protruding feature housing an undercling and upward-facing edge. (Note that this is _not_ the leftward trending crack incorrectly referred to on the OldPueblo bouldering site). A physical opening sequence lands you matched at the start of the stand. 

  Recommended.
content.protection: Pads, especially on the rock behind

content.description:
Climb the arete on the left side of the face. 

  Number 1

Begin matched on a blocky loaf-like hold at chest height and climb straight up through a sloping edge out right and bad heel hook 

  Number4

Start on Bear Down, and link from left to right into the chickenhead. Finish on #7. 

  Number 6

SDS on the leftward-trending crack left of the Left 8B Project and transition from poor to good rock up the face. Thin.  

  Number 6

Begin on Indian Summer and link from right to left into the chickenhead of Number 7. Finish on Number 7. 

  Number 11
This boulder offers unique features on superior granite. The best rock in the area by far and should not be missed.
